Question: How can the sun burn in the vaccum of space with no oxygen as a reactant?
Answer: 1. It doesn’t burn with oxygen.
2. There is a nuclear fusion reaction going on at the center of the sun, fusing hydrogen atoms into helium atoms.
3. This is more or less the same reaction that we are trying to implement in fusion reactors here on earth, so that we can get cheap plentiful energy.
4. This reaction produces massive amounts of heat, making the sun extremely hot.
5. As a result, the sun is so hot that it glows brilliantly - the same way that hot lava or molten metal does, only brighter.
6. That is how the sun shines.
7. Edit: nuclear fusion is not to be confused with nuclear fission, which breaks heavy atoms into smaller ones.
8. We do fission at all our nuclear reactors, but we don’t yet have any commercial fusion reactors.
9. The sun doesn’t do fission, only fusion.
output:
1. [Incomplete] Reasons: The reason for completeness is given below:"The Sun does not "burn" like we think of logs in a fire or paper burning. The Sun glows because it is a very big ball of gas, and a process called nuclear fusion is taking place in its core. Nuclear fusion occurs when one proton smashes into another proton so hard that they stick together...and release some energy as well. This energy then heats the other materials (other protons and electrons and such) nearby. This heating eventually grows out from the center (or core) of the star to the outside, finally leaving the surface and radiating out into space to be the heat and light we know stars emit. People, including scientists, sometimes say that the Sun "burns hydrogen" to make it glow. But that is just a figure of speech. Hydrogen doesn't burn, it fuses, into helium. So no oxygen is required".Source:https://starchild.gsfc.nasa.gov/docs/StarChild/questions/question36.html#:~:text=The%20Sun%20does%20not%20%22burn,taking%20place%20in%20its%20core.

Question: Is light different in nature from other frequencies in the electromagnetic spectrum? Let me rephrase the question - do we call the visible spectrum that because that's what we can see or is there something different about that part of electromagnetic spectrum (es) that allow vision to occur. Alternately, if light is dual in nature, being both a wave and a particle, is that the same for other parts of the es?
Answer: 1. Yes, there are creatures that can see outside of the human visible spectrum, but not very far.
2. Just a bit into the infrared and the ultraviolet.
3. As for why we can detect those wavelengths, two main reasons.
4. One, those wavelengths pass through water.
5. As it is believed that life started in the ocean, the first eyes would only have been able to detect light that could penetrate into the ocean.
6. Second, these wavelengths have the property that they can interact with small molecules.
7. Infrared light and longer wavelengths are too big and weak to effect much, and mostly just scatter off our cells.
8. Ultraviolet light and smaller wavelengths are too small and powerful, and will shoot right through our cells, mostly zipping right through but sometimes causing damage.
9. The wavelengths in between, however, can be absorbed by the right kind of molecule, and the energy of that absorption can be used to send a signal that “hey, I just caught a photon!
10. ” so yes, the visible range does have some special properties that make it suitable for use in vision.
11. I have heard anecdotal tales of insects being affected by very long wavelengths, like the 120 hz signal from power lines, but I have not seen any scientific confirmation.
12. It is possible that some creatures can detect wavelengths far from the visual spectrum in some way, but it wouldn’t be in the form of “vision.
13. ”

Question: How do people make money from their life insurance policies? I see people on Tiktok, ig, etc, talking about borrowing against their life insurance policies and doing real estate investing. I am entirely ignorant as to how most financial things work, and i'm guessing posts of that nature are an attempt to prey on that ignorance in some way or another.
Answer: 1. Whole life insurance policies accrue a cash value.
2. Basically at any point throughout the policies life cycle you could cash it in for that cash value.
3. That cash value is significantly lower than the payout of the insurance policy and it's based on a portion of your premium payments going into that cash value every time.
4. These people are then using that cash value as collateral to borrow money against which is totally possible.
5. The major failure point of this entire process is that whole life policies are basically garbage.
6. They tout the cash value growth as a way to draw you in as a potential investment.
7. But the reality is that the growth of those policies are typically extremely poor and most people in the financial sector would instead encourage you to buy a term life policy that would cover whatever you needed to.
8. So yes these tick tocks you are seeing are accurate however they're using some flawed foundations to share that content with you.
9. If for example somebody had bought you a whole life policy when you were a child and it has a crude cash value then you most certainly could tap into that but you should not go out and buy a whole life policy with the intention of doing this.

2. [Complete]

Question: Why does it take so long to fall asleep initially, but feels super easy when woken up by your alarm?
Answer: 1. Sleep, like a lot of functions in your body, is controlled by hormones.
2. To fall asleep your body needs to produce a certain amount of sleep hormones, as soon as that threshold is reached you fall asleep.
3. When you get woken up by your alarm and haven’t gotten enough sleep yet your body is still full of sleep hormones, so falling back asleep is really easy.
4. Then there are also sleep cycles, each cycle is around ~~3 hours~~ 90 minutes long.
5. If you get woken up near the beginning or end of a cycle you’ll probably feel more or less fine, but if you get woken up in the middle you'll feel super groggy and want to finish up the cycle as fast as possible.

Answer: 1. The heavier noble gases do have a full d-shell as well.
2. You can fill four successive s orbitals before a d-shell configuration becomes energetically favorable, so there is no d-shell for helium, neon, and argon.
3. Krypton has a filled d-orbital.
4. Helium only has a full 1s, no p or d.

11. That tends to go for a lot of aquatic creatures.
12. Most exist just to be food for other things.
13. As such, they have huge broods of offspring and the law of large numbers means enough survive to keep the species going.
14. There are some endangered fish we can't catch, and a lot of areas require fishing licenses and have restrictions on what people can catch without releasing.
15. So the same rules apply to those "smaller" fish.
16. It's just the way the food chain works we have a ton of those "smaller" fish and we have to do something really exceptional to endanger them.

Question: Why are there no nuclear bombs that only use hydrogen without any uranium? As far as I know, access to uranium is tightly controlled for obvious reasons, but hydrogen is everywhere, and even getting access to deuterium shouldn't be too hard.
Answer: 1. > people demonstrate achieving fusion all the time.
2. I mean, not *all* the time.
3. It takes a lot of equipment and power to create fusion, much less get a net energy gain out of it.
4. If you aren't in a massive test reactor you aren't going to be demonstrating fusion.
5. > when building a bomb, we don't really care about useful energy; we just want to release a lot of it.
6. We actually do care about useful energy since the aim is to make the fusion reaction release more energy than it took to start.
7. Otherwise we would just use whatever we used to start the reaction alone as the explosive.
8. And therein lies the problem: starting fusion is hard.
9. It requires immense temperatures and pressures which you aren't going to get out of conventional explosives.
10. You can't just have a fuse leading to deuterium and while hydrogen will burn violently when exposed to oxygen it isn't nearly as powerful as conventional chemical explosives.
11. Even carefully shaped charges using our most powerful conventional chemical explosives aren't going to fuse the material of a warhead.
12. Instead what we need is the power of a fission bomb to provide the heat and pressure to make the fusion fuel actually fuse and release even more energy.

Question: How are programming languages. . . Programmed? Basicly what the title says.
Answer: 1. The CPU of computers have, hard coded into then, a set of instructions that define the kinds of operations that computer can perform.
2. For example, adding two numbers.
3. These instructions are coded in binary.
4. For example, the instruction to add two numbers in memory (along with an optional constant) might look like:0010000xxxxxyyyyyzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzwhere the x's represent the location to find the first number.
5. The y's represent the location to find the second number, the z's represent the third constant, and the 0010000 is what tells the computer that this is an adding operation.
6. This is not a particularly intuitive representation.
7. So instead we might want to represent it with something more like language, like:"add x y z"but now we need a program that converts "add x y z", which we understand, into "0010000xxxxxyyyyyzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzz", which the computer understands.
8. So we make a program that does that, directly programming it with machine code.
9. This is how *assemblers* came into being.
10. This slightly-higher-level language was called assembly and the programs that would convert assembly into machine code were assemblers.
11. Higher level languages make the commands even more sensible and memorable, translate into multiple machine-level instructions with a single high-level command, and also optimize and streamline code.
12. The first high level languages would have been programmed in assembly, along with the programs to convert the high level language into machine language, called *compilers.
13. *today, we use high level languages to make *other* high level languages.

Question: How does rendering a video game resolution above your monitor resolution make the picture more crisp? You would think the resolution is already "maxed out", how does this improve things?
Answer: 1. It's called supersampling and basically gives the computer more options for what to render for any given pixel.
2. If you "render" at a higher resolution so that each final pixel is 4 pixels in the supersample then the computer gets 4 reference points for what color that pixel could be instead of just one.
3. It can then average those 4 values and get a cleaner value for that final pixel.
4. When you have high contrast areas (black against white for example) the computer can pick a cleaner average between the two areas (shades of gray) instead of only choosing between white and black.
output:
1. [Complete]
2. [Incomplete] Reasons: This information is not complete. Supersampling can be explained more than just averaging colors. Supersampling also includes smoothing the jagged edges from the images, a method known as spacial anti-aliasing.Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supersampling

Question: Where did the tradition of circumcision come from, and why?
Answer: 1. Male circumcision was an effective way to mark your tribe from birth in a way adults were unlikely to emulate.
2. Or it could be used as a test of bravery during an initiation into adulthood.
3. Eventually it became associated with certain religions.
output:

For example, Jewish culture evolved to consider the practice of circumcision on young neonate boys as part of forming a 'covenant with God' from birth, changing the time and order for which boys and men are permitted to be circumcised (formerly being the adolescent stage for young boys instead of neonate). Circumcision became an associated part of Abrahamic religions, Islam and Judaism, because of the belief that Abraham had a circumcision as part of marking the covenant between God and his people (the chosen people, the 'Children of Israel'). The African Lemba tribe (located on the Zimbabwe/South Africa border) practice adolescent circumcision because of the belief that they are the true Jewish people hailing from ancient Sana, a city located thousands of miles away from their contemporary habitat. The Lamba circumcision ritual consists of a process of seclusion, circumcision, welcoming back the secluded with songs and dancing, introducing dietary restrictions (similar to traditional Hebrew Jewish practices), and restricting marriage only to women of the tribe. Source:Doyle, D. *Ritual Male Circumcision: A Brief History*. Journal of the Royal College of Physicians. Edinburgh. 2005, (35). pp. 279–285.

Question: Did other ancient have travellers like the Europeans did? If so why do we focus so heavily on European history/advancements in schools? Edit: did other ancient civilizations have travelers like the Europeans did? If so why do we focus so heavily on European history/advancements in schools?
Answer: 1. They did, yes.
2. A samurai named [hasekura tsunenaga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/hasekura_tsunenaga), for example, traveled east across the pacific, all the way across north America, across the atlantic, visited much of Europe, and returned via colonial-era latin America, for example.
3. Wiki has a [list](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/list_of_explorers); here's a few notables:* [zhang qian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/zhang_qian), a 2nd century Chinese explorer who visited much of western asia and returned to China and is responsible in part for the establishment of the silk road (which would, itself, have hundreds of traveling merchants along its length).
4. * [zheng he](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/zheng_he), who explored much of south asia and east africa from his homeland in China.
5. * [ibn battuta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ibn_battuta), a berber who was the most traveled man known in the pre-modern world, who visited almost the entirety of the old world from South africa to Spain to russia to China to India.
6. He traveled more than 100,000 km in the 1300s, mostly from 1325 to 1347, which means he averaged around 12 km of travel *per day* for more than 20 years in a pre-industrial world.
7. In addition to these deliberate explorers, you'll find plenty of other people who ended up in cultures wildly different from their own, as with [yasuke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/yasuke), a slave or servant from Mozambique who ended up in the service of famous Japanese historical figure oda nobunaga.
8. We hear mostly about the Europeans because (a) you and I are speaking english and therefore are by nature working within a European cultural world and (b) European colonial power made early European explorers particularly important to world history, because they laid the groundwork for the eventual colonization of most of the world by Europe.
9. To really make the point on (a), ibn battuta's travels weren't known in Europe until more than 500 years after he died, despite there being *tons* of cultural contact between Europe and the muslim world.

3. Minimum wage laws were passed originally to force companies to pay people a living wage, meaning that every employee was making enough money to makes ends meet.
4. But with inflation the cost of living increases, so the minimum wage has to be increased to compensate.

11. So why is the minimum wage so low?
12. Decades of lobbying have kept the minimum wage low to benefit companies and protect corporate profits.
13. Now it's so low that increasing it too fast to what it should be will be a disaster and cause rampant inflation.
14. So it has to be increased steadily over a period of time.

Question: Why do crisps not go stale in the bag before it’s opened; aren’t they exposed to air? And why, even after the bag is open, will a clip over the bag keep them fresh whereas leaving them exposed to the same air will make them go stale?
Answer: 1. Chips go bad for two main reasons:* oxygen in the air reacts with the fats in the chips, and* the chips absorb water from the air and become slightly soggy.
2. The "air" in the bag is not actually air.
3. It's usually nitrogen gas, which isn't reactive and doesn't result in chemical changes in the food.
4. (air is also mostly nitrogen, but it's the parts that aren't - oxygen and water vapor - that are the problem.
5. )> and why, even after the bag is open, will a clip over the bag keep them fresh whereas leaving them exposed to the same air will make them go stale?
6. Any oxygen inside the bag is quickly consumed.
7. This does make the fats in the chips go ever so slightly rancid, but (a) not enough to really notice and (b) most foods have some antioxidant preservatives in them that can stop this process up to a point.
8. Similarly, any water is absorbed.
9. In an open bag, oxygen and water are constantly flowing it from the environment.
output:
1. [Complete]
2. [Complete]
3. [Complete]
4. [Complete]
5. [Complete]
6. [Complete]
7. [Complete]
8. [Incomplete] Reasons: The water absorption alters the starch and protein matrix within the crisps, which can change the strength of the material (they become softer).
9. [Incomplete] Reasons: This does not explain why "even after the bag is open, will a clip over the bag keep them fresh". The clip reduces the flow of the air around the chips, meaning that once the moisture/oxygen within the bag has reacted with the chips, the bag contains inert Nitrogen. By not clipping the bag, the moisture/oxygen can be readily replaced due to airflow - meaning that they can continually absorb moisture/oxygen and continue spoiling.

Question: Why would increasing base interest rates combat high costs of living? Prices are going up so let's put them up more by increasing the base level of interest. Why is this logical? What am I missing?

5. That is, inflation is now getting lower, and costs of living don’t rise as fast.

Question: Why do we forget things or lose memories over time?
Answer: 1. Former memory researcher, here.
2. Hypothetically, once a memory is encoded into long-term memory, it is there forever.
3. So when you can't remember something, it's not because it isn't there, but rather that you can't find your way back to that memory.
4. Think about a memory like a cabin in a dense forest.
5. If you visit that cabin often, there will be a well worn path to get there and its easy to find your way.
6. But when you don't visit a memory often, the path becomes overgrown and harder to find.
7. You may not be able to locate the cabin anymore.
8. Now, even if we don't visit our cabin often, we can leave ourselves clues on how to get there.
9. For instance, if you always have delicious smelling pies cooling on the windowsill of your cabin, you can use the smell and the path to get there.
10. So even if the path is worn down, you're not totally lost.
output:
1. [Complete]
2. [Incomplete] Reasons: Hypothetically yes, as in theory long-term memory does not have a defined time limit. However, in real life, not every long-term memory is going to be in the brain forever. I think it would be important to mention that aging can (and most likely at some point will) lead to long-term memory loss as the brain changes. Other factors can be neurodegenerative conditions or other medical issues like strokes. Just because every memory *could* stay in long-term memory forever doesn't mean it will, which does not become clear here.

Question: States rights vs federal rights and which one has priority
Answer: 1. Generally speaking (just in theory, it gets murkier in practice) the federal government has jurisdiction over things which the constitution explicitly gives it jurisdiction over; interstate commerce and national defense are two examples.
2. In these areas the federal government has the authority.
3. For example, ohio can’t say that people from kentucky can’t ship goods into ohio because that’s interstate commerce.
4. Everything not explicitly designated to the federal government by the constitution, such as education, waste collection, roads etc.
5. Is supposed to be the domain of the states.
6. In reality, we’ve had over two centuries of laws and court decisions that make this distinction way murkier than it probably was when the constitution was written, but that’s how it works in theory.
7. Edit: and as other people have mentioned, the supremacy clause means that when the jurisdiction overlaps, the federal government overrules the state government.

Question: Why were American civilizations so much less advanced than their European colonizers? Despite being around for just as long?
Answer: 1. It's not necessarily that they were less advanced.
2. The aztecs had irrigation and plumbing as well as city infrastructure that was superior to what was seen in Europe at the time.
3. They didn't have weapons on the same level.
4. And the trick is that doesn't matter how advanced your art is, how great you are at agriculture and growing plants, what sort of medical advances you may have made, if someone else has better weapons and can conquer you.
5. Now, part of these you also is that Europe was in a sweet spot that allowed for rapid technological growth compared to most of the rest of the world.
6. It wasn't just comparatively easier access to metals, but also that the mediterranean sea and many large rivers made rapid communication between different civilizations much easier, and that made it much easier for information to travel and thus improve.
7. If someone invents something in rome, it was very easy for that knowledge to make it to France, where it could be improved upon.
8. Likewise, the easier proximity between nations in Europe encouraged wars, which also made them focus a lot more on weapons technology development.
9. So while there are many ways that the natives of the americas had developed, their weapons technology was nowhere near enough to stand the chance against the Europeans.
10. That, combined with the impact of diseases that the Europeans brought, since they were more used to keeping domesticated animals, and of us getting more diseases from those, meant that the native americans didn't stand a chance.

For example, superior weapons were important during the Spanish conquest of the Aztec empire. However, while Cortes's force had superior weapons they lacked the numbers needed for total conquest of the Aztecs. Instead, Cortes relied on divisions among the peoples of Central Mexico, exploiting these to form alliances against the Mexicas (leaders of the Aztec empire) - thus, the conquest of the Aztecs was less about sheer force through advanced weaponry and more about superior strategy both militarily and politically. Furthermore, the aspect of cultural traditions was also a deciding factor in the success of the Spanish conquest of the Aztecs - the latter allowed Cortes to reinforce his lieutenant and commander of the Spanish garrison outside Tenochtitlan, Alvarado, resulting in a strengthening of the Spanish line at a point when they were themselves divided and weakened. The Aztecs allowed such a thing to happen because of their ceremonial tradition that war must be fought en-masse and head-on, not through more Anglo/euro-centric concepts like 'divide and conquer'. Question: Canada is raising interest again to prevent a recession. How does this work?
Answer: 1. First you have to realize it’s all related to inflation.
2. Inflation simply means that goods and services cost more now than they used to.
3. Next you have to understand the law of supply and demand and how they relate to pricing.
4. If supply is high and demand is low, prices go down.
5. If demand is high and supply is low, prices go up.
6. Combining these two, we can understand that prices are going up, because demand for those good and services is going up.
7. So how does changing interest rates affect this?
8. Well when interest rates are low, companies and people tend to take on more loans, since they are able to get that money cheaply.
9. With more money to spend, they want to make use of that money, so they buy goods and services.
10. But as already discussed, that means more demand, which means prices go up even more.
11. But we don’t want prices to go up now, we want prices to go down.
12. The only way to make prices go down is to either increase the supply more than the demand (something that a government can’t do in a capitalist society) or decrease demand.
13. How can they decrease demand?
14. Raise interest rates.
15. With higher interest rates, companies and individuals do not borrow as much.
16. As interest rates get higher, not only are they not borrowing as much, they are instead saving more and more of the money they do have.
17. So raising interest rates lowers the amount of money being spent on goods and services, which lowers demand, which lowers prices.

Question: How do ozone machine get rid of odors and why is it dangerous to use without property ppe?
Answer: 1. Oxygen is a *very* grabby element.
2. It wants to hold onto electrons very tightly, which is why it forms very strong bonds with things like carbon.
3. Oxygen essentially can't exist on its own, it's too reactive.
4. So, oxygen in the air is mostly in the form o2, where two oxygen atoms are sharing their electrons with each other.
5. However, it really *doesn't* like sharing its electrons with other oxygen atoms, because they all want to grab the electrons, like a game of tug of war.
6. So when you put *three* oxygen atoms together (ozone, o3) they **really** don't want to share, even a little bit.
7. They'll share with o2 well enough but a third oxygen atom just is not welcome to that party.
8. As soon as the ozone comes into contact with anything else, one of the oxygen atoms will pop off and grab onto that other thing, hard.
9. Oxygen grabs harder than almost any other element, so if the oxygen grabs onto an atom, the atom may have to let go of an atom that it was holding.
10. In this way, the "lone" single oxygen atom tears apart other molecules.
11. If that molecule is a smelly odor-causing molecule, it gets torn up and probably doesn't cause an odor anymore.
12. If you just have a bunch of o2, that will still kind of happen but it takes a little more energy to get the two oxygen atoms to fall apart.
13. Even if they don't like sharing, if one oxygen atom leaves, the other would be alone which is too unstable, so they tend to stay together unless both of them get bind to new atoms.
14. If you have a bunch of free oxygen atoms, they will immediate react with each other and pair up, or react to whatever you're trying to hold them in an burn/explode.
15. Ozone splits that difference - stable enough to carry around that extra oxygen that can react to things, but not so unstable that it reacts before it has a chance to get there.
16. It's dangerous because ozone doesn't particularly care what it's reacting with.
17. If it gets in your lungs, it'll do the same thing to all the molecules in your lungs that it will do to odor molecules in the air.
18. If it gets into your blood, it'll do the same thing to molecules in your blood.
19. It's just not a great thing to get in your body.
20. It's fine if the levels in the air are low enough - after all, as long as it's reacting to stuff in the air then it's destroying itself before much of it can get to you.
21. If the levels get too high, though, enough of it will survive long enough to get to you, and then you have a problem.

Question: Why is smoking weed “better” than smoking cigarettes or vaping? Aren’t you inhaling harmful foreign substances in all cases?
Answer: 1. Short answer : in absolute terms, smoking weed creates more tar and other nasty compounds than tobacco.
2. However, you normally smoke a **lot** less weed than your do tobacco.
3. Second, substances in smoked cannabis also trigger/enhance apoptosis.
4. That’s the process that causes cells with mutations or other damage to stop reproducing and die.
5. We *think* that there are better outcomes with pot, and fewer instances of problems because apoptosis triggers cause damaged cells to die rather than hanging around and reproducing, and accumulating more damage until they hit a malignant mutation.
6. **edit**: apoptosis is not a good or bad thing.
7. It’s a programmed form of cell death that does not only occur in damaged cells.
8. It triggers it in healthy cells too.
9. Like most things in medicine, whether it is good or bad is a matter of degree and circumstance.
10. The endocannabinoids may be helpful in protecting against long term damage from cannabis use, and *also* damaging in other ways.
11. Even the “bad” effects - like immune suppression ( it triggers cell death very efficiently in certain kinds of immune cells ) - can be beneficial in the right circumstances.
12. They are being studied as a way to help prevent death from acute respiratory distress, and “cytokine storms” where the immune response runs of control in a dangerous, or even lethal fashion.
13. **edit 2**: anything you set on fire is going to produce compounds that are bad for your lungs.
14. Pot smoke is also bad for your lungs, as is the smoke from incense, candles, wood and anything else you burn.
15. Pot [smoke] is “safer” than tobacco [smoke] in some ways, and worse in others.
16. Reality is complicated, biology even more so.

3. In the case of farts, most of the gas (\~75%) is hydrogen, carbon dioxide, and methane.

8. By comparison, a grain of rice weighs about 29 mg.
9. Other smells are typically gases too.
10. They are organic molecules that stick to proteins in our noses and stimulate nerves that our brain interprets as smells.

Question: Why are antivirals less commonly used to treated viral infections unlike antibiotics for bacteria and antifungals for fungi?
Answer: 1. Antivirals just aren't as good as antibiotics.
2. There are a lot of antibiotics that are very good at killing bacteria, and will kill lots of different kinds of bacteria.
3. So if you have a bacterial infection, even if you don't know exactly what kind of bacteria you have, you can often take an antibiotic that will do a great job of killing whatever it is that you have.
4. You can take it for maybe just a few days and be basically cured.
5. In contrast, antivirals are pretty lousy.
6. None of the antivirals we have are effective against more than a narrow family of viruses.
7. And most of them are pretty wimpy even there, requiring either multi-drug cocktails, treatment durations measured in weeks, and/or are able to only suppress the virus and not really cure you of it.
8. Also, a lot of the antivirals that we have are fairly toxic, and tend to cause a lot of side effects.
9. If antivirals were better, we'd probably use them more.
10. Antibiotics are amazing, and so we use them a lot.
11. We probably overuse them, but even if this weren't the case, there'd still be lots of opportunities for appropriate use.

Question: Why does food break down so easily as opposed to something like a rock which does not break down easily?
Answer: 1. The molecules in food are much less stable than the molecules (or, well, crystals) in a rock, and your body has a wide range of digestive enzymes (special proteins that accelerate the rate of chemical reactions) that are specifically made to break down the molecules found in your food.
2. Bread, for example, is mostly starch.
3. Starch, in turn, is a chain of loosely-bonded molecules of glucose (a type of simple sugar).
4. Your saliva, and the pancreatic juice that mixes in when food enters your intestine, contain a family of enzymes called *amylases* that attack the bonds between the glucose molecules, splitting the starches into simple sugars.
5. Those sugars then dissolve across your intestinal wall into your blood and are available for use by your body.
output:
1. [Incomplete] Reasons: Most foods are constituted of Organic compounds - in the form of carbohydrates (containing the elements Carbon, Hydrogen, Oxygen, or Nitrogen).Rocks, on the other hand, tend to be Inorganic compounds (Metal salts like Iron, Magnesium, or Aluminium). Our bodies have evolved to be powered by organic molecules, although we can digest certain salts (such as NaCl (table salt)).
2. [Complete]
3. [Complete]
4. [Complete]
5. [Incomplete] Reasons: Put simply, we are not evolved to break down other types of energy sources (e.g. rocks in this case) because the energy required to break apart such structures would not be beneficial. The body has a net energy gain by digesting simple carbohydrates; this would not be the case for inorganic sources where the crystal lattices, etc., contain more energy. Additionally, there are toxic effects of these metal salts, etc.

Question: When adhd people take meds that increase dopamine, when does this dopamine gets converted into norepinephrine? Is the conversion instant , gradual or do you have to wait for all dopamine to be converted to norepinephrine ?
Answer: 1. Typical medications for adhd don't increase production of dopamine.
2. They act on mobilizing what you already make, getting it into action between nerves.
3. Medications that actually increase dopamine synthesis are instead used for parkinson's, where there's actually a loss of dopamine-producing cells.
4. They don't work well for adhd.
5. ---------------------------------------------edit: some more information as there's often a lot of curiosity around similar questions.
6. Basically, while many psychiatric problems seem to involve some sort of alterations in how the brain uses various neurotransmitters to function, none are as simple as "too little of this" or "too much of that.
7. " (classic narcolepsy, on the other hand, actually does involve destruction of cells that produce a neurotransmitter called orexin or hypocretin; parkinson's, as above, involves loss of dopamine neurons.
8. That said, both can involve psychiatric symptoms.
9. )dopamine in particular is a curious chemical, which the brain and body use for many different functions, and where the timing/size/location of a dopamine signal can make a lot of difference.
10. For instance, unless you're breastfeeding or taking certain medications right now, dopamine is constantly, 24/7/365, telling part of your brain not to fire up milk production.
11. (you've been taking it for granted, all these years.
12. ) in other areas, dopamine has curious roles involve movement, reward/prediction, and motivation.
13. As you can imagine, it's very important that a signal related to movement or reward be timed correctly.
14. Fundamentally, the brain is always trying to figure out "was that thing I just did good or not, and would the benefit of doing the same thing or another thing be worth the effort and risk?
15. " it's sometimes described as a pleasure molecule but that's probably not very accurate, and other neurotransmitters probably have a stronger role.
16. Researchers have modeled adhd around failure of the frontal cortex (the part of the brain that's supposed to take charge and connect behavior to goals) to use neurotransmitters like dopamine and norepinephrine to adequately rein in the rest of the brain, probably with related alterations in reward processing.
17. This doesn't tell us everything, but as a working model it helps connect symptoms that might not otherwise seem related but show up together, like inattention, impulsivity, and hyperactivity.

Question: Why does food need to be cooled to room temperature before refrigeration?
Answer: 1. Food safety professional here.
2. This is actually a very poor idea as it puts the food in the ideal conditions for spoilage for a longer time.
3. The danger zone for food spoilage is 40-140f, so you want to hold food at those temperatures for as little time as possible.
4. The thoughts about hot food overworking your fridge or warming other foods up to the danger zone may ha e had a grain of truth a long time ago, but nowadays it is a myth, as modern refrigerators are more than capable of sufficiently cooling whatever is put into it.
5. The best practice is to take food and place it in shallow containers, then immediately place it in the fridge.
6. This is what promotes the fastest cooling, and maintains your food in as safe a condition as possible.
7. Edit: fun fact showing the importance of shallow containers.
8. The very center of a soup/stew/chili in a large stock pot can take up to 24 hours to get completely cooled down

Question: Why are binoculars and riflescopes expressed in magnification, but camera lenses are expressed in focal length?
Answer: 1. The practice of using focal length for camera lenses originated from the first bellows cameras.
2. It let you know how far you needed to extend the lens designed for a specific sized image circle for a distant object to be in sharpest focus at the focal plane.
3. When lens mounts replaced bellows and lenses started using multiple elements the industry should have shifted to magnification or field of view, but it didn't.
4. This practice continued until long after it was practical or meaningful to describe a lens by focal length.
5. The focal length is directly related to the size of the imaging circle at the focal plane.
6. The focal length numbers you see are typically referred to as "35mm equivalent" meaning that this is what the focal length would have been if it was a lens for a 35mm system.
7. Lots of modern digital cameras have much smaller image sensors than 35mm.
8. The iphone's actual focal length is less than 3mm but it is only ever referred to as a focal length of 26mm as that would be its "35mm equivalent.
9. "today all lenses have multiple complex lens elements that allow the designer to place the focal plane at any desired distance from the front of the lens.
10. This means that in practice focal length means literally nothing even on 35mm systems.
11. I have a 35mm lens that is much longer than my 85mm lens.
12. Also note that the imaging circle for 35mm systems isn't even 35mm because of course it isn't.
13. The diagonal of 35mm film is 43.
14. 27mm, so the image circle has to be at least that big to cover the full frame of the film.
15. So what does focal length really mean?
16. It tells you how far from the focal plane the front of the lens would need to be if it were a single element lens and the imaging circle needs to be 44mm and you wanted to focus at a distant object.
17. Implicit in all of this is the thing you really want to know - the field of view of the lens.
18. **tl;dr: camera lenses use "focal length" for century-old legacy reasons, none of which make any sense today but it still kind of works because of the relationship to field of view and the standardization of the 35mm format.
19. Binoculars and rifle scopes use magnification and aperture because it's the sane thing to do.
20. **

Question: Why does splitting an atom create a bomb does this also work if you split a singular atom? Or do you have to split multiple atoms to make a bomb? How do you split an atom anyways? ?
Answer: 1. Imagine you've got a mousetrap set up so that when it snaps, it throws a bunch of bb's in alll directions.
2. Put thousands of these mousetraps together in a room and snap one of them.
3. It throws its bbs, which will almost certainly snap more mousetraps, which throw even more bbs which snaps even more mousetraps.
4. This process continues until the mousetraps are all (or mostly) used up.
5. The same happens with splitting atoms.
6. By bombarding uranium atoms (mousetraps) with neutrons (bbs), you can destabilize them, causing them to break apart.
7. When they do, they'll release a bunch of energy and more neutrons.
8. Those neutrons then hit other uranium atoms, causing them to split and continuing the chain reaction.

However, not all elements will behave like this and cause a chain reaction. Some atoms, such as Boron, can simply absorb the neutrons and be used to slow down the rate of neutron release. This is how we harness and control nuclear power reactors.

Question: Is inflation inevitable in all successful economies? Throughout history, has there ever been a society that maintained 0% inflation for a long term while still maintaining a good quality of life?
Answer: 1. To answer that question you need to understand what inflation is exactly.
2. Currency and wealth are two different things.
3. Wealth is stuff of value for human, either a product, a natural resource or a service.
4. Currency is just something that help trade wealth.
5. There is a relationship of supply and demand between the two.
6. The supply is the currency and the demand is the wealth, because the more wealth you have the more you want to trade it with others.
7. In general, wealth increase over time.
8. The population increase so more worker, the technology and education increase so we are more productive, etc.
9. So this mean that if demand (wealth) increase, but the supply (currency) stay the same, then the value of the currency will increase, which would be deflation.
10. But if we add currency to the economy faster than the wealth increase, then we get more supply than demand, which lead to a decrease in the value of the supply (currency), we call that inflation.
11. So as a country you can decide how much currency you want to add to the economy to control like a valve how much deflation or inflation you want.
12. But unlike a valve, this is a very complex and dynamic problem.
13. You can try to estimate how much wealth will increase, but you will never estimate exactly.
14. You also can't simply add an exact amount of currency in the economy, you need to add it indirectly (too complicated to explain here).
15. So even if you wanted to stay at 0% inflation, that would just be impossible.
16. So usually countries try to target about 2% inflation.
17. That way with natural variation you should vary between 0 and 4% inflation, which are all relatively healthy level of inflation.
18. You don't want to go into deflation long term or too high of an inflation.
19. The other advantage of targeting 2% is that a little bit of inflation is actually good.
20. It incentivize people to invest their money instead of keeping it.
21. Money invested is money that do work and that's good for economic growth.
22. So no it would be physically impossible to keep your inflation at 0%, but even if it was possible that wouldn't be good for economic growth.

Question: The controversy surrounding general electric as run under jack welch or jeff immelt? I had a reading for my mba class tonight that was a piece written by jeff immelt, former CEO of general electric, right before he left the company. The class discussion was probably the most animated discussion of the whole class so far. [the article](https://hbr.org/2017/09/inside-ges-transformation) on its own merits didn't seem controversial, as they were standard change management material, but emotions ran high during discussion, and I was confused.
Answer: 1. Jack welch created ge finance, which provided in-house finance for ge products.
2. Ge finance was *wildly* profitable, but there was a lack of understanding of the cause of this success among ge's leadership.
3. They viewed ge finance as being the entity driving the company and invested heavily in it, while neglecting investment in ge's industrial arm.
4. This set up for a situation where chronic underinvestment caused ge's product line to stall and quality to drop.
5. By the time that welch left, he'd sort of set up a time bomb where ge products were rapidly becoming obsolete trash.
6. Because ge finance's business was almost exclusively financing purchases of ge products, when ge's product line started to tank, ge finance tanked as well.
7. This wouldn't have necessarily been a problem, because one thing welch did quite well was to turn ge into a major exporter and ge had built up a **huge** pile of overseas cash.
8. Immelt inherited that cash pile and could have used it to revamp ge's product line.
9. He didn't.
10. An unwillingness to pay us tax on overseas profit caused immelt to refuse to invest the money in us manufacturing.
11. At the same time, a fear of foreign countries nationalizing ge overseas investments also stopped immelt from investing in overseas production (and this was a well founded fear in the early 2000's - backdoor nationalizations were common at the time).
12. So instead of investing the cash into ge's business, immelt just let it sit in foreign bank accounts, doing absolutely nothing, and most of ge's business just sort of rotted away under him.

13. Usually the usd (hence the term) but, in theory, could be any currency.
14. Informal dollarization occurs when citizens and businesses do this anyway and refuse to transact or hold local currency.

Question: Why can people bail out of jail?
Answer: 1. In the us (and some other nations), the legal system is set up with the presumption that an a person accused of a crime is innocent until proven guilty.
2. Thus, it would be wrong to force people to possibly be imprisoned--maybe for years, waiting for trial--if they are actually innocent.
3. However, if accused people are simply arrested and released, many do not return to court to face the criminal accusations (whether they are innocent or guilty).
4. So, a bail system was developed, so that a person had to provide some kind of security that he would return to court.
5. If the person on bail does not return, the court claims the money, which can then be used to help track down the person and bring them before the court.

Question: What does a surety underwriter do? This is what my dad does at a large insurance company and I have no idea what it means. I’m 25 and I feel like it’s too late to ask lol
Answer: 1. If I want to operate a business, sometimes there's a chance that I could screw up and break something really big.
2. If i'm a doctor, I could prescribe something wrong or do a surgery wrong and kill someone.
3. If i'm a car manufacturer, I could build a car that occasionally catches on fire and burns the people inside to death.
4. If I pour concrete sidewalks, I could do a bad job and create a substantial tripping hazard (obviously not as bad as killing someone, but still a problem that costs more to deal with than the profit I make from that single job).
5. ​in order to make sure that the people aren't completely screwed when they're victims of big problems that come from a business like that, states require that those businesses keep a big pile of money available to pay out if there is a big problem.
6. That big pile of money is too big for most companies to keep sitting unused all the time, so the businesses buy surety bonds.
7. Those aren't the same kind of bonds as "stocks and bonds" on wall street.

Question: How do torrents work? Isn't a torrent just, like. . . Directly sharing a file from your pc? What's all this business about "seeding" and "leeching"?
Answer: 1. It is basically like directly sharing, but not quite.
2. A file (it can be anything) is separated into many smaller pieces, each getting a special name.
3. The torrent basically holds this information and the instructions on how to assemble the smaller pieces into one piece, the original file.
4. This instruction (a torrent) is coupled with additional information which keeps track of various computers across the internet which have the same torrent and which pieces of the original file they have.
5. This additional information is called trackers.
6. When you download a specific torrent and run it using software made to read it, the software knows what smaller pieces of the larger file you lack (when you begin you lack all of them) and it checks which computers have those smaller pieces.
7. Then it downloads the smaller pieces from any available computer which has them.
8. Once it has all the pieces, they are assembled into the original file.
9. Seeders is the name for the computers which the entire file and thus all the smaller pieces.
10. Leechers is the name for the computers which do not have the entire file, but rather any amount of the smaller pieces.
11. The benefit of the system is that you can download any piece from any computer which has it, be they seeders or leechers, as long as those computers are currently running the torrent software and are connected to the internet.
12. So, in short, torrents help by distributing a file to as many people as possible and allow anyone to download that file by taking pieces from everyone until they have the whole thing.
13. This way nobody is dependant on one place that holds the file.
14. If someone disconnects or deletes the file it is still available to download from the other people who have it.
15. Of course, if everyone who has the complete file were to delete it, nobody would be able to get the full file anymore.
output:

The complete description of seeders refers to computers within the torrent community that have downloaded the complete file and are actively sharing that file.

Question: When you fill up a glass with ice and water, why does the volume of water in the glass stay the same even after the ice has melted? Like, if I fill up a glass 3/4 of ice and the rest with water, the glass is still at the same water level even after the ice has melted. You would think the water would take up more volume once in its liquid state….
Answer: 1. > you would think the water would take up more volume once in its liquid state….
2. You might think that, and most materials that would be true, but water has the rare quality that its solid state actually takes up **more** volume than its liquid state.
3. This is after all why it floats, as it displaces more volume than its weight in liquid water.
4. As for why the water level doesn't change, anything floating in water will displace its weight equivalent in volume of water.
5. So if a ship weighs 100 tons it would displace a volume of water equal to 100 tons; if its hull isn't big enough to do that then it will sink!
6. Ice takes up slightly more volume than liquid water so a bit of ice pokes up out of the water as it floats, but when it melts it reduces in volume and takes up precisely the volume it displaced meaning the water level doesn't change.
output:
1. [Complete]
2. [Incomplete] Reasons: An explanation of why this is the case would be beneficial - liquid water is more dense as the liquid molecules of H2O are attracted to each other by hydrogen bonding. This is when there are polar interactions between the slightly negatively charged oxygen atoms and the slightly positively charged hydrogen atoms in water molecules (opposites attract). The converse is also true, and repulsive interactions occur between similarly charged ends. In the solid state, the more rigid structure means that the water molecules are more spread out since they would equally want to minimize the repulsion between positive-positive or negative-negative ends of the molecules. However, in the liquid state, the molecules are free-flowing and therefore less spread out (therefore more dense).
3. [Incomplete] Reasons: The answer would be improved if this definition of density was explained - Ice floats because it is less dense than the liquid water it is in. This means that the molecules in the ice take up more volume than the equivalent number of molecules of liquid water. Imagine a rock - it is the opposite of ice, as a rock is more dense than ice, and liquid water, and therefore it sinks.

Question: What is the difference between a condo and a housing co-op?
Answer: 1. In a condo situation the individual owners own their units and the condo association owns the common property.
2. Each individual owner contributes a share to the association and the association uses that money to maintain the common property.
3. A condominium cannot restrict the rights of buyers or sellers.
4. In a co-op the co-op owns everything and individuals buy a "share" of the whole - that share including their individual unit and a portion of the common property.
5. Because the co-op owns the whole, they can legally refuse to sell to someone who doesn't meet the co-ops standards, because the person buying in isn't buying the unit as a separate entity, but the unit as a "share" of the whole.
output:
1. [Complete]
2. [Complete]
3. [Incomplete] Reasons: This answer could do with listing what these rights are. For example, the right to sell, rent, or mortgage your unit.Source:https://www.quickenloans.com/learn/co-op-vs-condo#:~:text=If%20you%20live%20in%20a,the%20community%20that%20manages%20it.
4. [Complete]
5. [Complete]

Answer: 1. The human eye uses a large lens which focuses light onto the retina.

3. A downside is that very bright lights like the sun get focused onto the delicate retina so intensely, it causes damage.

5. These eyes have an excellent field of view and ability to detect motion, but aren't so sensitive to light.
6. Overall, insect eyes don't focus light as intensely, and focus it onto less sensitive tissue.

Answer: 1. The rise in borrowing costs has been mentioned which is true, but it also represents a bit of a paradigm shift that was a surprise to markets.
2. The Japanese central bank had been keeping rates effectively zero whilst other central banks had been rising to manage inflation.
3. Japan has not seen the same inflation as most other markets, for a number of reasons.
4. Japan’s monetary policy remains very accommodative, but this is a move in the opposite direction, albeit somewhat marginal.
5. The break in rhetoric from the bank of Japan caught market participants but surprise and markets reacted accordingly; bonds fell to adjust to the new rate regime expectations, equity markets overall fell, financial stocks rose, and the yen rallied.
6. The australian stock market fell sharply as a flow on effect - there is a common trade (“carry trade”) whereby you borrow in Japan cheaply to invest in higher yielding markets like Australia.
7. The rise in rates makes this less attractive, especially if there is more of this to come.
8. Investors therefore would have closed out their higher yield paying offshore “long” positions and their “short” yen position which was the cheap borrowing leg.

Question: Why are California catalytic converters 3x the price of the same model elsewhere in the lower 48? Tagged in econ but not really sure it fits here either. Thanks all.
Answer: 1. Carb mandated warranties are to blame for the inflated prices.
2. A carb-compliant catalytic converter is one that has been approved for sale by the California air resources board (carb).
3. Carb emission standards for aftermarket catalytic converters are more elaborate than the epa standards for aftermarket catalytic converters and requires a more extensive warranty than the epa.
4. As a result, carb-compliant catalytic converters typically use an enhanced combination of washcoat technology and higher precious metal load to meet the stricter emissions conversions standard.
5. A carb-compliant converter will also have an executive order (eo) number/stamp on its body.
6. The stamped number on the converter body must match the correct eo number listed on the California air resources board website for aftermarket catalytic converters.

2. Growing crops?

4. The internet?

7. Electricity.
8. Iron/steel/copper/aluminum?
9. Coal and energy in the form of heat or electricity.

11. We're shifting toward more renewables, but it still only makes up a small part of our energy use.
12. Nuclear provided a lot, but once you take into consideration transport uses it's pretty small.
13. Oil subsidies generally work to keep supply, and therefore prices for energy, stable.
14. Also, to expand supply before demand pushes oil prices too high.
15. That's the main benefit.
16. Keeping prices for the input to everything we do stable.
17. Global inflation is up recently due to a lot of factors.
18. But a big one is energy prices, because fundamentally everything's price is dependent in part on how much energy costs.
19. You really just need to look at a graph of inflation and oil prices.
20. You'll notice that when oil prices go up, inflation does too.
21. When it goes down, inflation is low.
22. They're not 100% aligned, but there's an impact.
